\subsection*{First Reading}

\subsubsection*{The First Lesson}
\centerline{\textit{Judith 14}}
A reading from the Book of Judith, beginning with the fourteenth chapter, the first verse\\

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{14} Then Judith said to them, “Listen to me, my friends. Take this head and hang it upon the parapet of your wall. \textsuperscript{2} As soon as day breaks and the sun rises on the earth, each of you take up your weapons, and let every able-bodied man go out of the town; set a captain over them, as if you were going down to the plain against the Assyrian outpost; only do not go down. \textsuperscript{3} Then they will seize their arms and go into the camp and rouse the officers of the Assyrian army. They will rush into the tent of Holofernes and will not find him. Then panic will come over them, and they will flee before you. \textsuperscript{4} Then you and all who live within the borders of Israel will pursue them and cut them down in their tracks. \textsuperscript{5} But before you do all this, bring Achior the Ammonite to me so that he may see and recognize the man who despised the house of Israel and sent him to us as if to his death. ” \textsuperscript{6} So they summoned Achior from the house of Uzziah. When he came and saw the head of Holofernes in the hand of one of the men in the assembly of the people, he fell down on his face in a faint. \textsuperscript{7} When they raised him up he threw himself at Judith’s feet, and did obeisance to her, and said, “Blessed are you in every tent of Judah! In every nation those who hear your name will be alarmed. \textsuperscript{8} Now tell me what you have done during these days. ” So Judith told him in the presence of the people all that she had done, from the day she left until the moment she began speaking to them. \textsuperscript{9} When she had finished, the people raised a great shout and made a joyful noise in their town. \textsuperscript{10} When Achior saw all that the God of Israel had done, he believed firmly in God. So he was circumcised, and joined the house of Israel, remaining so to this day. \textsuperscript{11} As soon as it was dawn they hung the head of Holofernes on the wall. Then they all took their weapons, and they went out in companies to the mountain passes. \textsuperscript{12} When the Assyrians saw them they sent word to their commanders, who then went to the generals and the captains and to all their other officers. \textsuperscript{13} They came to Holofernes’ tent and said to the steward in charge of all his personal affairs, “Wake up our lord, for the slaves have been so bold as to come down against us to give battle, to their utter destruction. ” \textsuperscript{14} So Bagoas went in and knocked at the entry of the tent, for he supposed that he was sleeping with Judith. \textsuperscript{15} But when no one answered, he opened it and went into the bedchamber and found him sprawled on the floor dead, with his head missing. \textsuperscript{16} He cried out with a loud voice and wept and groaned and shouted, and tore his clothes. \textsuperscript{17} Then he went to the tent where Judith had stayed, and when he did not find her, he rushed out to the people and shouted, \textsuperscript{18} “The slaves have tricked us! One Hebrew woman has brought disgrace on the house of King Nebuchadnezzar. Look, Holofernes is lying on the ground, and his head is missing! ” \textsuperscript{19} When the leaders of the Assyrian army heard this, they tore their tunics and were greatly dismayed, and their loud cries and shouts rose up throughout the camp.
\end{quote}

Here ends the Reading.\\

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Thursday after the Twenty-third Sunday after Pentecost, or the Twenty-second Sunday after Trinity (Proper 28)}}
Stir up, O Lord, the wills of your faithful people, that bringing forth in abundance the fruit of good works, they may be abundantly rewarded when our Savior Jesus Christ comes to restore all things; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Edmund, King of East Anglia and Martyr, 870}}
Almighty God, you gave your servant Edmund boldness to confess the Name of our Savior Jesus Christ before the rulers of this world, and courage to die for this faith: Grant that we may always be ready to give a reason for the hope that is in us, and to suffer gladly for the sake of our Lord Jesus Christ; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Guidance}
\centerline{\textit{Thursday}}
Heavenly Father, in you we live and move and have our being: We humbly pray you so to guide and govern us by your Holy Spirit, that in all the cares and occupations of our life we may not forget you, but may remember that we are ever walking in your sight; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
Almighty and everlasting God, who alone works great marvels: Send down upon our clergy and the congregations committed to their charge the life-giving Spirit of your grace, shower them with the continual dew of your blessing, and ignite in them a zealous love of your Gospel; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

We ought at all times humbly to acknowledge our sins before Almighty God, but especially when we come together in his presence to give thanks for the great benefits we have received at his hands, to declare his most worthy praise, to hear his holy Word, and to ask, for ourselves and on behalf of others, those things which are necessary for our life and our salvation. \subsection*{First Reading}

\subsubsection*{The First Lesson}
\centerline{\textit{Judith 15}}
A reading from the Book of Judith, beginning with the fifteenth chapter, the first verse\\

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{15} When the men in the tents heard it, they were amazed at what had happened. \textsuperscript{2} Overcome with fear and trembling, they did not wait for one another, but with one impulse all rushed out and fled by every path across the plain and through the hill country. \textsuperscript{3} Those who had camped in the hills around Bethulia also took to flight. Then the Israelites, everyone that was a soldier, rushed out upon them. \textsuperscript{4} Uzziah sent men to Betomasthaim and Choba and Kola, and to all the frontiers of Israel, to tell what had taken place and to urge all to rush out upon the enemy to destroy them. \textsuperscript{5} When the Israelites heard it, with one accord they fell upon the enemy, and cut them down as far as Choba. Those in Jerusalem and all the hill country also came, for they were told what had happened in the camp of the enemy. The men in Gilead and in Galilee outflanked them with great slaughter, even beyond Damascus and its borders. \textsuperscript{6} The rest of the people of Bethulia fell upon the Assyrian camp and plundered it, acquiring great riches. \textsuperscript{7} And the Israelites, when they returned from the slaughter, took possession of what remained. Even the villages and towns in the hill country and in the plain got a great amount of booty, since there was a vast quantity of it. \textsuperscript{8} Then the high priest Joakim and the elders of the Israelites who lived in Jerusalem came to witness the good things that the Lord had done for Israel, and to see Judith and to wish her well. \textsuperscript{9} When they met her, they all blessed her with one accord and said to her, “You are the glory of Jerusalem, you are the great boast of Israel, you are the great pride of our nation! \textsuperscript{10} You have done all this with your own hand; you have done great good to Israel, and God is well pleased with it. May the Almighty Lord bless you forever! ” And all the people said, “Amen. ” \textsuperscript{11} All the people plundered the camp for thirty days. They gave Judith the tent of Holofernes and all his silver dinnerware, his beds, his bowls, and all his furniture. She took them and loaded her mules and hitched up her carts and piled the things on them. \textsuperscript{12} All the women of Israel gathered to see her, and blessed her, and some of them performed a dance in her honor. She took ivy-wreathed wands in her hands and distributed them to the women who were with her; \textsuperscript{13} and she and those who were with her crowned themselves with olive wreaths. She went before all the people in the dance, leading all the women, while all the men of Israel followed, bearing their arms and wearing garlands and singing hymns. \textsuperscript{14} Judith began this thanksgiving before all Israel, and all the people loudly sang this song of praise.
\end{quote}

Here ends the Reading.\\

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Friday after the Twenty-third Sunday after Pentecost, or the Twenty-second Sunday after Trinity (Proper 28)}}
Stir up, O Lord, the wills of your faithful people, that bringing forth in abundance the fruit of good works, they may be abundantly rewarded when our Savior Jesus Christ comes to restore all things; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Endurance}
\centerline{\textit{Friday}}
Almighty God, whose most dear Son went not up to joy but first he suffered pain, and entered not into glory before he was crucified: Mercifully grant that we, walking in the way of the Cross, may find it none other than the way of life and peace; through Jesus Christ your Son our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
Lord Jesus Christ, you stretched out your arms of love on the hard wood of the Cross that everyone might come within the reach of your saving embrace: So clothe us in your Spirit that we, reaching forth our hands in love, may bring those who do not know you to the knowledge and love of you; for the honor of your Name.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

Almighty God, you have given us grace at this time, with one accord to make our common supplications to you; and you have promised through your well-beloved Son that when two or three are gathered together in his Name you will grant their requests: Fulfill now, O Lord, our desires and petitions as may be best for us; granting us in this world knowledge of your truth, and in the age to come life everlasting.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\centerline{\textit{Judith 16}}
A reading from the Book of Judith, beginning with the sixteenth chapter, the first verse\\

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{16} \textsuperscript{1} And Judith said, Begin a song to my God with tambourines, sing to my Lord with cymbals. Raise to him a new psalm; exalt him, and call upon his name. \textsuperscript{2} For the Lord is a God who crushes wars; he sets up his camp among his people; he delivered me from the hands of my pursuers. \textsuperscript{3} The Assyrian came down from the mountains of the north; he came with myriads of his warriors; their numbers blocked up the wadis, and their cavalry covered the hills. \textsuperscript{4} He boasted that he would burn up my territory, and kill my young men with the sword, and dash my infants to the ground, and seize my children as booty, and take my virgins as spoil. \textsuperscript{5} But the Lord Almighty has foiled them by the hand of a woman. \textsuperscript{6} For their mighty one did not fall by the hands of the young men, nor did the sons of the Titans strike him down, nor did tall giants set upon him; but Judith daughter of Merari with the beauty of her countenance undid him. \textsuperscript{7} For she put away her widow’s clothing to exalt the oppressed in Israel. She anointed her face with perfume; \textsuperscript{8} she fastened her hair with a tiara and put on a linen gown to beguile him. \textsuperscript{9} Her sandal ravished his eyes, her beauty captivated his mind, and the sword severed his neck! \textsuperscript{10} The Persians trembled at her boldness, the Medes were daunted at her daring. \textsuperscript{11} Then my oppressed people shouted; my weak people cried out, and the enemy trembled; they lifted up their voices, and the enemy were turned back. \textsuperscript{12} Sons of slave-girls pierced them through and wounded them like the children of fugitives; they perished before the army of my Lord. \textsuperscript{13} I will sing to my God a new song: O Lord, you are great and glorious, wonderful in strength, invincible. \textsuperscript{14} Let all your creatures serve you, for you spoke, and they were made. You sent forth your spirit, and it formed them; there is none that can resist your voice. \textsuperscript{15} For the mountains shall be shaken to their foundations with the waters; before your glance the rocks shall melt like wax. But to those who fear you you show mercy. \textsuperscript{16} For every sacrifice as a fragrant offering is a small thing, and the fat of all whole burnt offerings to you is a very little thing; but whoever fears the Lord is great forever. \textsuperscript{17} Woe to the nations that rise up against my people! The Lord Almighty will take vengeance on them in the day of judgment; he will send fire and worms into their flesh; they shall weep in pain forever. \textsuperscript{18} When they arrived at Jerusalem, they worshiped God. As soon as the people were purified, they offered their burnt offerings, their freewill offerings, and their gifts. \textsuperscript{19} Judith also dedicated to God all the possessions of Holofernes, which the people had given her; and the canopy that she had taken for herself from his bedchamber she gave as a votive offering. \textsuperscript{20} For three months the people continued feasting in Jerusalem before the sanctuary, and Judith remained with them. \textsuperscript{21} After this they all returned home to their own inheritances. Judith went to Bethulia, and remained on her estate. For the rest of her life she was honored throughout the whole country. \textsuperscript{22} Many desired to marry her, but she gave herself to no man all the days of her life after her husband Manasseh died and was gathered to his people. \textsuperscript{23} She became more and more famous, and grew old in her husband’s house, reaching the age of one hundred five. She set her maid free. She died in Bethulia, and they buried her in the cave of her husband Manasseh; \textsuperscript{24} and the house of Israel mourned her for seven days. Before she died she distributed her property to all those who were next of kin to her husband Manasseh, and to her own nearest kindred. \textsuperscript{25} No one ever again spread terror among the Israelites during the lifetime of Judith, or for a long time after her death.
\end{quote}

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{21} Now after these events Paul resolved in the Spirit to pass through Macedonia and Achaia and go to Jerusalem, saying, “After I have been there, I must also see Rome. ” \textsuperscript{22} And having sent into Macedonia two of his helpers, Timothy and Erastus, he himself stayed in Asia for a while. \textsuperscript{23} About that time there arose no little disturbance concerning the Way. \textsuperscript{24} For a man named Demetrius, a silversmith, who made silver shrines of Artemis, brought no little business to the craftsmen. \textsuperscript{25} These he gathered together, with the workmen in similar trades, and said, “Men, you know that from this business we have our wealth. \textsuperscript{26} And you see and hear that not only in Ephesus but in almost all of Asia this Paul has persuaded and turned away a great many people, saying that gods made with hands are not gods. \textsuperscript{27} And there is danger not only that this trade of ours may come into disrepute but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis may be counted as nothing, and that she may even be deposed from her magnificence, she whom all Asia and the world worship. ” \textsuperscript{28} When they heard this they were enraged and were crying out, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians! ” \textsuperscript{29} So the city was filled with the confusion, and they rushed together into the theater, dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus, Macedonians who were Paul's companions in travel. \textsuperscript{30} But when Paul wished to go in among the crowd, the disciples would not let him. \textsuperscript{31} And even some of the Asiarchs, who were friends of his, sent to him and were urging him not to venture into the theater. \textsuperscript{32} Now some cried out one thing, some another, for the assembly was in confusion, and most of them did not know why they had come together. \textsuperscript{33} Some of the crowd prompted Alexander, whom the Jews had put forward. And Alexander, motioning with his hand, wanted to make a defense to the crowd. \textsuperscript{34} But when they recognized that he was a Jew, for about two hours they all cried out with one voice, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians! ” \textsuperscript{35} And when the town clerk had quieted the crowd, he said, “Men of Ephesus, who is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is temple keeper of the great Artemis, and of the sacred stone that fell from the sky? \textsuperscript{36} Seeing then that these things cannot be denied, you ought to be quiet and do nothing rash. \textsuperscript{37} For you have brought these men here who are neither sacrilegious nor blasphemers of our goddess. \textsuperscript{38} If therefore Demetrius and the craftsmen with him have a complaint against anyone, the courts are open, and there are proconsuls. Let them bring charges against one another. \textsuperscript{39} But if you seek anything further, it shall be settled in the regular assembly. \textsuperscript{40} For we really are in danger of being charged with rioting today, since there is no cause that we can give to justify this commotion. ” \textsuperscript{41} And when he had said these things, he dismissed the assembly.
\end{quote}

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Saturday after the Twenty-third Sunday after Pentecost, or the Twenty-second Sunday after Trinity (Proper 28)}}
Stir up, O Lord, the wills of your faithful people, that bringing forth in abundance the fruit of good works, they may be abundantly rewarded when our Savior Jesus Christ comes to restore all things; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Cecilia, Martyr at Rome, c. 230}}
Almighty God, you gave your servant Cecilia boldness to confess the Name of our Savior Jesus Christ before the rulers of this world, and courage to die for this faith: Grant that we may always be ready to give a reason for the hope that is in us, and to suffer gladly for the sake of our Lord Jesus Christ; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Sabbath Rest}
\centerline{\textit{Saturday}}
Almighty God, who after the creation of the world rested from all your works and sanctified a day of rest for all your creatures: Grant that we, putting away all earthly anxieties, may be duly prepared for the service of your sanctuary, and that our rest here upon earth may be a preparation for the eternal rest promised to your people in heaven; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
O God, you have made of one blood all the peoples of the earth, and sent your blessed Son to preach peace to those who are far off and to those who are near: Grant that people everywhere may seek after you and find you; bring the nations into your fold; pour out your Spirit upon all flesh; and hasten the coming of your kingdom; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{First Reading}

\subsubsection*{The First Lesson}
\centerline{\textit{Sirach 1}}
A reading from Ecclesiasticus, the Wisdom of Jesus Son of Sirach, beginning with the first chapter, the first verse\\

\begin{quote}
Many great teachings have been given to us through the Law and the Prophets and the others that followed them, and for these we should praise Israel for instruction and wisdom. Now, those who read the scriptures must not only themselves understand them, but must also as lovers of learning be able through the spoken and written word to help the outsiders. So my grandfather Jesus, who had devoted himself especially to the reading of the Law and the Prophets and the other books of our ancestors, and had acquired considerable proficiency in them, was himself also led to write something pertaining to instruction and wisdom, so that by becoming familiar also with his book those who love learning might make even greater progress in living according to the law. You are invited therefore to read it with goodwill and attention, and to be indulgent in cases where, despite our diligent labor in translating, we may seem to have rendered some phrases imperfectly. For what was originally expressed in Hebrew does not have exactly the same sense when translated into another language. Not only this book, but even the Law itself, the Prophecies, and the rest of the books differ not a little when read in the original. When I came to Egypt in the thirty-eighth year of the reign of Euergetes and stayed for some time, I found opportunity for no little instruction. It seemed highly necessary that I should myself devote some diligence and labor to the translation of this book. During that time I have applied my skill day and night to complete and publish the book for those living abroad who wished to gain learning and are disposed to live according to the law. \textsuperscript{1} All wisdom is from the Lord, and with him it remains forever. \textsuperscript{2} The sand of the sea, the drops of rain, and the days of eternity—who can count them? \textsuperscript{3} The height of heaven, the breadth of the earth, the abyss, and wisdom—who can search them out? \textsuperscript{4} Wisdom was created before all other things, and prudent understanding from eternity. \textsuperscript{6} The root of wisdom—to whom has it been revealed? Her subtleties—who knows them? \textsuperscript{8} There is but one who is wise, greatly to be feared, seated upon his throne—the Lord. \textsuperscript{9} It is he who created her; he saw her and took her measure; he poured her out upon all his works, \textsuperscript{10} upon all the living according to his gift; he lavished her upon those who love him. \textsuperscript{11} The fear of the Lord is glory and exultation, and gladness and a crown of rejoicing. \textsuperscript{12} The fear of the Lord delights the heart, and gives gladness and joy and long life. \textsuperscript{13} Those who fear the Lord will have a happy end; on the day of their death they will be blessed. \textsuperscript{14} To fear the Lord is the beginning of wisdom; she is created with the faithful in the womb. \textsuperscript{15} She made among human beings an eternal foundation, and among their descendants she will abide faithfully. \textsuperscript{16} To fear the Lord is fullness of wisdom; she inebriates mortals with her fruits; \textsuperscript{17} she fills their whole house with desirable goods, and their storehouses with her produce. \textsuperscript{18} The fear of the Lord is the crown of wisdom, making peace and perfect health to flourish. \textsuperscript{19} She rained down knowledge and discerning comprehension, and she heightened the glory of those who held her fast. \textsuperscript{20} To fear the Lord is the root of wisdom, and her branches are long life. \textsuperscript{22} Unjust anger cannot be justified, for anger tips the scale to one’s ruin. \textsuperscript{23} Those who are patient stay calm until the right moment, and then cheerfulness comes back to them. \textsuperscript{24} They hold back their words until the right moment; then the lips of many tell of their good sense. \textsuperscript{25} In the treasuries of wisdom are wise sayings, but godliness is an abomination to a sinner. \textsuperscript{26} If you desire wisdom, keep the commandments, and the Lord will lavish her upon you. \textsuperscript{27} For the fear of the Lord is wisdom and discipline, fidelity and humility are his delight. \textsuperscript{28} Do not disobey the fear of the Lord; do not approach him with a divided mind. \textsuperscript{29} Do not be a hypocrite before others, and keep watch over your lips. \textsuperscript{30} Do not exalt yourself, or you may fall and bring dishonor upon yourself. The Lord will reveal your secrets and overthrow you before the whole congregation, because you did not come in the fear of the Lord, and your heart was full of deceit.
\end{quote}

Here ends the Reading.\\

A reading from the Acts of the Apostles, beginning with the twentieth chapter, the first verse\\

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{20} After the uproar ceased, Paul sent for the disciples, and after encouraging them, he said farewell and departed for Macedonia. \textsuperscript{2} When he had gone through those regions and had given them much encouragement, he came to Greece. \textsuperscript{3} There he spent three months, and when a plot was made against him by the Jews as he was about to set sail for Syria, he decided to return through Macedonia. \textsuperscript{4} Sopater the Berean, son of Pyrrhus, accompanied him; and of the Thessalonians, Aristarchus and Secundus; and Gaius of Derbe, and Timothy; and the Asians, Tychicus and Trophimus. \textsuperscript{5} These went on ahead and were waiting for us at Troas, \textsuperscript{6} but we sailed away from Philippi after the days of Unleavened Bread, and in five days we came to them at Troas, where we stayed for seven days. \textsuperscript{7} On the first day of the week, when we were gathered together to break bread, Paul talked with them, intending to depart on the next day, and he prolonged his speech until midnight. \textsuperscript{8} There were many lamps in the upper room where we were gathered. \textsuperscript{9} And a young man named Eutychus, sitting at the window, sank into a deep sleep as Paul talked still longer. And being overcome by sleep, he fell down from the third story and was taken up dead. \textsuperscript{10} But Paul went down and bent over him, and taking him in his arms, said, “Do not be alarmed, for his life is in him. ” \textsuperscript{11} And when Paul had gone up and had broken bread and eaten, he conversed with them a long while, until daybreak, and so departed. \textsuperscript{12} And they took the youth away alive, and were not a little comforted. \textsuperscript{13} But going ahead to the ship, we set sail for Assos, intending to take Paul aboard there, for so he had arranged, intending himself to go by land. \textsuperscript{14} And when he met us at Assos, we took him on board and went to Mitylene. \textsuperscript{15} And sailing from there we came the following day opposite Chios; the next day we touched at Samos; and the day after that we went to Miletus. \textsuperscript{16} For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus, so that he might not have to spend time in Asia, for he was hastening to be at Jerusalem, if possible, on the day of Pentecost.
\end{quote}

The Word of the Lord.\\

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{The Last Sunday after Pentecost: Christ the King}}
Almighty and everlasting God, whose will it is to restore all things in your well-beloved Son, the King of kings and Lord of lords: Mercifully grant that the peoples of the earth, divided and enslaved by sin, may be freed and brought together under his most gracious rule; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Clement, Bishop of Rome and Martyr, c. 100}}
O God, our heavenly Father, you raised up your faithful servant Clement of Rome to be Bishop and pastor in your Church and to feed your flock: Give abundantly to all pastors the gifts of your Holy Spirit, that they may minister in your household as true servants of Christ and stewards of your divine mysteries; through Jesus Christ our Lord, who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Strength to Await Christ's Return}
\centerline{\textit{Sunday}}
O God our King, by the resurrection of your Son Jesus Christ on the first day of the week, you conquered sin, put death to flight, and gave us the hope of everlasting life: Redeem all our days by this victory; forgive our sins, banish our fears, make us bold to praise you and to do your will; and steel us to wait for the consummation of your kingdom on the last great Day; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
Almighty and everlasting God, who alone works great marvels: Send down upon our clergy and the congregations committed to their charge the life-giving Spirit of your grace, shower them with the continual dew of your blessing, and ignite in them a zealous love of your Gospel; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Monday after the Last Sunday after Pentecost: Christ the King}}
Almighty and everlasting God, whose will it is to restore all things in your well-beloved Son, the King of kings and Lord of lords: Mercifully grant that the peoples of the earth, divided and enslaved by sin, may be freed and brought together under his most gracious rule; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for the Renewal of Life}
\centerline{\textit{Monday}}
O God, the King eternal, whose light divides the day from the night and turns the shadow of death into the morning: Drive far from us all wrong desires, incline our hearts to keep your law, and guide our feet into the way of peace; that, having done your will with cheerfulness during the day, we may, when night comes, rejoice to give you thanks; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
Lord Jesus Christ, you stretched out your arms of love on the hard wood of the Cross that everyone might come within the reach of your saving embrace: So clothe us in your Spirit that we, reaching forth our hands in love, may bring those who do not know you to the knowledge and love of you; for the honor of your Name.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{4} My child, do not cheat the poor of their living, and do not keep needy eyes waiting. \textsuperscript{2} Do not grieve the hungry, or anger one in need. \textsuperscript{3} Do not add to the troubles of the desperate, or delay giving to the needy. \textsuperscript{4} Do not reject a suppliant in distress, or turn your face away from the poor. \textsuperscript{5} Do not avert your eye from the needy, and give no one reason to curse you; \textsuperscript{6} for if in bitterness of soul some should curse you, their Creator will hear their prayer. \textsuperscript{7} Endear yourself to the congregation; bow your head low to the great. \textsuperscript{8} Give a hearing to the poor, and return their greeting politely. \textsuperscript{9} Rescue the oppressed from the oppressor; and do not be hesitant in giving a verdict. \textsuperscript{10} Be a father to orphans, and be like a husband to their mother; you will then be like a son of the Most High, and he will love you more than does your mother. \textsuperscript{11} Wisdom teaches her children and gives help to those who seek her. \textsuperscript{12} Whoever loves her loves life, and those who seek her from early morning are filled with joy. \textsuperscript{13} Whoever holds her fast inherits glory, and the Lord blesses the place she enters. \textsuperscript{14} Those who serve her minister to the Holy One; the Lord loves those who love her. \textsuperscript{15} Those who obey her will judge the nations, and all who listen to her will live secure. \textsuperscript{16} If they remain faithful, they will inherit her; their descendants will also obtain her. \textsuperscript{17} For at first she will walk with them on tortuous paths; she will bring fear and dread upon them, and will torment them by her discipline until she trusts them, and she will test them with her ordinances. \textsuperscript{18} Then she will come straight back to them again and gladden them, and will reveal her secrets to them. \textsuperscript{19} If they go astray she will forsake them, and hand them over to their ruin. \textsuperscript{20} Watch for the opportune time, and beware of evil, and do not be ashamed to be yourself. \textsuperscript{21} For there is a shame that leads to sin, and there is a shame that is glory and favor. \textsuperscript{22} Do not show partiality, to your own harm, or deference, to your downfall. \textsuperscript{23} Do not refrain from speaking at the proper moment, and do not hide your wisdom. \textsuperscript{24} For wisdom becomes known through speech, and education through the words of the tongue. \textsuperscript{25} Never speak against the truth, but be ashamed of your ignorance. \textsuperscript{26} Do not be ashamed to confess your sins, and do not try to stop the current of a river. \textsuperscript{27} Do not subject yourself to a fool, or show partiality to a ruler. \textsuperscript{28} Fight to the death for truth, and the Lord God will fight for you. \textsuperscript{29} Do not be reckless in your speech, or sluggish and remiss in your deeds. \textsuperscript{30} Do not be like a lion in your home, or suspicious of your servants. \textsuperscript{31} Do not let your hand be stretched out to receive and closed when it is time to give.

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Tuesday after the Last Sunday after Pentecost: Christ the King}}
Almighty and everlasting God, whose will it is to restore all things in your well-beloved Son, the King of kings and Lord of lords: Mercifully grant that the peoples of the earth, divided and enslaved by sin, may be freed and brought together under his most gracious rule; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Catherine of Alexandria, Martyr, c. 305}}
Almighty God, you gave your servant Catherine of Alexandria boldness to confess the Name of our Savior Jesus Christ before the rulers of this world, and courage to die for this faith: Grant that we may always be ready to give a reason for the hope that is in us, and to suffer gladly for the sake of our Lord Jesus Christ; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Peace}
\centerline{\textit{Tuesday}}
O God, the author of peace and lover of concord, to know you is eternal life and to serve you is perfect freedom: Defend us, your humble servants, in all assaults of our enemies; that we, surely trusting in your defense, may not fear the power of any adversaries, through the might of Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
O God, you have made of one blood all the peoples of the earth, and sent your blessed Son to preach peace to those who are far off and to those who are near: Grant that people everywhere may seek after you and find you; bring the nations into your fold; pour out your Spirit upon all flesh; and hasten the coming of your kingdom; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{and all the blessings of this life;}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{but above all for your immeasurable love}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{in the redemption of the world by our Lord Jesus Christ;}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{for the means of grace, and for the hope of glory.}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{And, we pray, give us such an awareness of your mercies,}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{that with truly thankful hearts we may show forth your praise,}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{not only with our lips, but in our lives,}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{by giving up our selves to your service,}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{and by walking before you}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{in holiness and righteousness all our days;}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{Through Jesus Christ our Lord,}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{to whom, with you and the Holy Spirit,}}\\
{\setlength{\leftskip}{2em}\setlength{\parindent}{0em}\textbf{be honor and glory throughout all ages. Amen.}}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer of St. John Chrysostom}
Almighty God, you have given us grace at this time, with one accord to make our common supplications to you; and you have promised through your well-beloved Son that when two or three are gathered together in his Name you will grant their requests: Fulfill now, O Lord, our desires and petitions as may be best for us; granting us in this world knowledge of your truth, and in the age to come life everlasting.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Wednesday after the Last Sunday after Pentecost: Christ the King}}
Almighty and everlasting God, whose will it is to restore all things in your well-beloved Son, the King of kings and Lord of lords: Mercifully grant that the peoples of the earth, divided and enslaved by sin, may be freed and brought together under his most gracious rule; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Grace}
\centerline{\textit{Wednesday}}
O Lord, our heavenly Father, almighty and everlasting God, you have brought us safely to the beginning of this day: Defend us by your mighty power, that we may not fall into sin nor run into any danger; and that, guided by your Spirit, we may do what is righteous in your sight; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
Almighty and everlasting God, who alone works great marvels: Send down upon our clergy and the congregations committed to their charge the life-giving Spirit of your grace, shower them with the continual dew of your blessing, and ignite in them a zealous love of your Gospel; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\centerline{\textit{Sirach 7}}
A reading from Ecclesiasticus, the Wisdom of Jesus Son of Sirach, beginning with the seventh chapter, the first verse\\

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{7} Do no evil, and evil will never overtake you. \textsuperscript{2} Stay away from wrong, and it will turn away from you. \textsuperscript{3} Do not sow in the furrows of injustice, and you will not reap a sevenfold crop. \textsuperscript{4} Do not seek from the Lord high office, or the seat of honor from the king. \textsuperscript{5} Do not assert your righteousness before the Lord, or display your wisdom before the king. \textsuperscript{6} Do not seek to become a judge, or you may be unable to root out injustice; you may be partial to the powerful, and so mar your integrity. \textsuperscript{7} Commit no offense against the public, and do not disgrace yourself among the people. \textsuperscript{8} Do not commit a sin twice; not even for one will you go unpunished. \textsuperscript{9} Do not say, “He will consider the great number of my gifts, and when I make an offering to the Most High God, he will accept it. ” \textsuperscript{10} Do not grow weary when you pray; do not neglect to give alms. \textsuperscript{11} Do not ridicule a person who is embittered in spirit, for there is One who humbles and exalts. \textsuperscript{12} Do not devise a lie against your brother, or do the same to a friend. \textsuperscript{13} Refuse to utter any lie, for it is a habit that results in no good. \textsuperscript{14} Do not babble in the assembly of the elders, and do not repeat yourself when you pray. \textsuperscript{15} Do not hate hard labor or farm work, which was created by the Most High. \textsuperscript{16} Do not enroll in the ranks of sinners; remember that retribution does not delay. \textsuperscript{17} Humble yourself to the utmost, for the punishment of the ungodly is fire and worms. \textsuperscript{18} Do not exchange a friend for money, or a real brother for the gold of Ophir. \textsuperscript{19} Do not dismiss a wise and good wife, for her charm is worth more than gold. \textsuperscript{20} Do not abuse slaves who work faithfully, or hired laborers who devote themselves to their task. \textsuperscript{21} Let your soul love intelligent slaves; do not withhold from them their freedom. \textsuperscript{22} Do you have cattle? Look after them; if they are profitable to you, keep them. \textsuperscript{23} Do you have children? Discipline them, and make them obedient from their youth. \textsuperscript{24} Do you have daughters? Be concerned for their chastity, and do not show yourself too indulgent with them. \textsuperscript{25} Give a daughter in marriage, and you complete a great task; but give her to a sensible man. \textsuperscript{26} Do you have a wife who pleases you? Do not divorce her; but do not trust yourself to one whom you detest. \textsuperscript{27} With all your heart honor your father, and do not forget the birth pangs of your mother. \textsuperscript{28} Remember that it was of your parents you were born; how can you repay what they have given to you? \textsuperscript{29} With all your soul fear the Lord, and revere his priests. \textsuperscript{30} With all your might love your Maker, and do not neglect his ministers. \textsuperscript{31} Fear the Lord and honor the priest, and give him his portion, as you have been commanded: the first fruits, the guilt offering, the gift of the shoulders, the sacrifice of sanctification, and the first fruits of the holy things. \textsuperscript{32} Stretch out your hand to the poor, so that your blessing may be complete. \textsuperscript{33} Give graciously to all the living; do not withhold kindness even from the dead. \textsuperscript{34} Do not avoid those who weep, but mourn with those who mourn. \textsuperscript{35} Do not hesitate to visit the sick, because for such deeds you will be loved. \textsuperscript{36} In all you do, remember the end of your life, and then you will never sin.
\end{quote}

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Thanksgiving Day (United States)}}
Most merciful Father, we humbly thank you for all your gifts so freely bestowed upon us: for life and health and safety, for strength to work and leisure to rest, for all that is beautiful in creation and in human life; but above all we thank you for our spiritual mercies in Christ Jesus our Lord; who with you and the Holy Spirit lives and reigns, one God, for ever and ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Thursday after the Last Sunday after Pentecost: Christ the King}}
Almighty and everlasting God, whose will it is to restore all things in your well-beloved Son, the King of kings and Lord of lords: Mercifully grant that the peoples of the earth, divided and enslaved by sin, may be freed and brought together under his most gracious rule; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Guidance}
\centerline{\textit{Thursday}}
Heavenly Father, in you we live and move and have our being: We humbly pray you so to guide and govern us by your Holy Spirit, that in all the cares and occupations of our life we may not forget you, but may remember that we are ever walking in your sight; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
Lord Jesus Christ, you stretched out your arms of love on the hard wood of the Cross that everyone might come within the reach of your saving embrace: So clothe us in your Spirit that we, reaching forth our hands in love, may bring those who do not know you to the knowledge and love of you; for the honor of your Name.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

We ought at all times humbly to acknowledge our sins before Almighty God, but especially when we come together in his presence to give thanks for the great benefits we have received at his hands, to declare his most worthy praise, to hear his holy Word, and to ask, for ourselves and on behalf of others, those things which are necessary for our life and our salvation. Therefore, draw near with me to the throne of heavenly grace.}\\

\centerline{\textit{Sirach 9}}
A reading from Ecclesiasticus, the Wisdom of Jesus Son of Sirach, beginning with the ninth chapter, the first verse\\

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{9} Do not be jealous of the wife of your bosom, or you will teach her an evil lesson to your own hurt. \textsuperscript{2} Do not give yourself to a woman and let her trample down your strength. \textsuperscript{3} Do not go near a loose woman, or you will fall into her snares. \textsuperscript{4} Do not dally with a singing girl, or you will be caught by her tricks. \textsuperscript{5} Do not look intently at a virgin, or you may stumble and incur penalties for her. \textsuperscript{6} Do not give yourself to prostitutes, or you may lose your inheritance. \textsuperscript{7} Do not look around in the streets of a city, or wander about in its deserted sections. \textsuperscript{8} Turn away your eyes from a shapely woman, and do not gaze at beauty belonging to another; many have been seduced by a woman’s beauty, and by it passion is kindled like a fire. \textsuperscript{9} Never dine with another man’s wife, or revel with her at wine; or your heart may turn aside to her, and in blood you may be plunged into destruction. \textsuperscript{10} Do not abandon old friends, for new ones cannot equal them. A new friend is like new wine; when it has aged, you can drink it with pleasure. \textsuperscript{11} Do not envy the success of sinners, for you do not know what their end will be like. \textsuperscript{12} Do not delight in what pleases the ungodly; remember that they will not be held guiltless all their lives. \textsuperscript{13} Keep far from those who have power to kill, and you will not be haunted by the fear of death. But if you approach them, make no misstep, or they may rob you of your life. Know that you are stepping among snares, and that you are walking on the city battlements. \textsuperscript{14} As much as you can, aim to know your neighbors, and consult with the wise. \textsuperscript{15} Let your conversation be with intelligent people, and let all your discussion be about the law of the Most High. \textsuperscript{16} Let the righteous be your dinner companions, and let your glory be in the fear of the Lord. \textsuperscript{17} A work is praised for the skill of the artisan; so a people’s leader is proved wise by his words. \textsuperscript{18} The loud of mouth are feared in their city, and the one who is reckless in speech is hated.
\end{quote}

Here ends the Reading.\\

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Friday after the Last Sunday after Pentecost: Christ the King}}
Almighty and everlasting God, whose will it is to restore all things in your well-beloved Son, the King of kings and Lord of lords: Mercifully grant that the peoples of the earth, divided and enslaved by sin, may be freed and brought together under his most gracious rule; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Endurance}
\centerline{\textit{Friday}}
Almighty God, whose most dear Son went not up to joy but first he suffered pain, and entered not into glory before he was crucified: Mercifully grant that we, walking in the way of the Cross, may find it none other than the way of life and peace; through Jesus Christ your Son our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
O God, you have made of one blood all the peoples of the earth, and sent your blessed Son to preach peace to those who are far off and to those who are near: Grant that people everywhere may seek after you and find you; bring the nations into your fold; pour out your Spirit upon all flesh; and hasten the coming of your kingdom; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

A reading from Ecclesiasticus, the Wisdom of Jesus Son of Sirach, beginning with the tenth chapter, the first verse\\

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{10} A wise magistrate educates his people, and the rule of an intelligent person is well ordered. \textsuperscript{2} As the people’s judge is, so are his officials; as the ruler of the city is, so are all its inhabitants. \textsuperscript{3} An undisciplined king ruins his people, but a city becomes fit to live in through the understanding of its rulers. \textsuperscript{4} The government of the earth is in the hand of the Lord, and over it he will raise up the right leader for the time. \textsuperscript{5} Human success is in the hand of the Lord, and it is he who confers honor upon the lawgiver. \textsuperscript{6} Do not get angry with your neighbor for every injury, and do not resort to acts of insolence. \textsuperscript{7} Arrogance is hateful to the Lord and to mortals, and injustice is outrageous to both. \textsuperscript{8} Sovereignty passes from nation to nation on account of injustice and insolence and wealth. \textsuperscript{9} How can dust and ashes be proud? Even in life the human body decays. \textsuperscript{10} A long illness baffles the physician; the king of today will die tomorrow. \textsuperscript{11} For when one is dead he inherits maggots and vermin and worms. \textsuperscript{12} The beginning of human pride is to forsake the Lord; the heart has withdrawn from its Maker. \textsuperscript{13} For the beginning of pride is sin, and the one who clings to it pours out abominations. Therefore the Lord brings upon them unheard-of calamities, and destroys them completely. \textsuperscript{14} The Lord overthrows the thrones of rulers, and enthrones the lowly in their place. \textsuperscript{15} The Lord plucks up the roots of the nations, and plants the humble in their place. \textsuperscript{16} The Lord lays waste the lands of the nations, and destroys them to the foundations of the earth. \textsuperscript{17} He removes some of them and destroys them, and erases the memory of them from the earth. \textsuperscript{18} Pride was not created for human beings, or violent anger for those born of women. \textsuperscript{19} Whose offspring are worthy of honor? Human offspring. Whose offspring are worthy of honor? Those who fear the Lord. Whose offspring are unworthy of honor? Human offspring. Whose offspring are unworthy of honor? Those who break the commandments. \textsuperscript{20} Among family members their leader is worthy of honor, but those who fear the Lord are worthy of honor in his eyes. \textsuperscript{22} The rich, and the eminent, and the poor— their glory is the fear of the Lord. \textsuperscript{23} It is not right to despise one who is intelligent but poor, and it is not proper to honor one who is sinful. \textsuperscript{24} The prince and the judge and the ruler are honored, but none of them is greater than the one who fears the Lord. \textsuperscript{25} Free citizens will serve a wise servant, and an intelligent person will not complain. \textsuperscript{26} Do not make a display of your wisdom when you do your work, and do not boast when you are in need. \textsuperscript{27} Better is the worker who has goods in plenty than the boaster who lacks bread. \textsuperscript{28} My child, honor yourself with humility, and give yourself the esteem you deserve. \textsuperscript{29} Who will acquit those who condemn themselves? And who will honor those who dishonor themselves? \textsuperscript{30} The poor are honored for their knowledge, while the rich are honored for their wealth. \textsuperscript{31} One who is honored in poverty, how much more in wealth! And one dishonored in wealth, how much more in poverty!
\end{quote}

\textsuperscript{12} When it was day, the Jews made a plot and bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink till they had killed Paul. \textsuperscript{13} There were more than forty who made this conspiracy. \textsuperscript{14} They went to the chief priests and elders and said, “We have strictly bound ourselves by an oath to taste no food till we have killed Paul. \textsuperscript{15} Now therefore you, along with the council, give notice to the tribune to bring him down to you, as though you were going to determine his case more exactly. And we are ready to kill him before he comes near. ” \textsuperscript{16} Now the son of Paul's sister heard of their ambush, so he went and entered the barracks and told Paul. \textsuperscript{17} Paul called one of the centurions and said, “Take this young man to the tribune, for he has something to tell him. ” \textsuperscript{18} So he took him and brought him to the tribune and said, “Paul the prisoner called me and asked me to bring this young man to you, as he has something to say to you. ” \textsuperscript{19} The tribune took him by the hand, and going aside asked him privately, “What is it that you have to tell me? ” \textsuperscript{20} And he said, “The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the council tomorrow, as though they were going to inquire somewhat more closely about him. \textsuperscript{21} But do not be persuaded by them, for more than forty of their men are lying in ambush for him, who have bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink till they have killed him. And now they are ready, waiting for your consent. ” \textsuperscript{22} So the tribune dismissed the young man, charging him, “Tell no one that you have informed me of these things. ” \textsuperscript{23} Then he called two of the centurions and said, “Get ready two hundred soldiers, with seventy horsemen and two hundred spearmen to go as far as Caesarea at the third hour of the night. \textsuperscript{24} Also provide mounts for Paul to ride and bring him safely to Felix the governor. ” \textsuperscript{25} And he wrote a letter to this effect: \textsuperscript{26} “Claudius Lysias, to his Excellency the governor Felix, greetings. \textsuperscript{27} This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them when I came upon them with the soldiers and rescued him, having learned that he was a Roman citizen. \textsuperscript{28} And desiring to know the charge for which they were accusing him, I brought him down to their council. \textsuperscript{29} I found that he was being accused about questions of their law, but charged with nothing deserving death or imprisonment. \textsuperscript{30} And when it was disclosed to me that there would be a plot against the man, I sent him to you at once, ordering his accusers also to state before you what they have against him. ” \textsuperscript{31} So the soldiers, according to their instructions, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris. \textsuperscript{32} And on the next day they returned to the barracks, letting the horsemen go on with him. \textsuperscript{33} When they had come to Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they presented Paul also before him. \textsuperscript{34} On reading the letter, he asked what province he was from. And when he learned that he was from Cilicia, \textsuperscript{35} he said, “I will give you a hearing when your accusers arrive. ” And he commanded him to be guarded in Herod's praetorium.
\end{quote}

The Word of the Lord.\\
\textbf{Thanks be to God.}\\

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Saturday after the Last Sunday after Pentecost: Christ the King}}
Almighty and everlasting God, whose will it is to restore all things in your well-beloved Son, the King of kings and Lord of lords: Mercifully grant that the peoples of the earth, divided and enslaved by sin, may be freed and brought together under his most gracious rule; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{Clive Staples Lewis, Teacher of the Faith, 1963}}
Almighty God, you gave your servant C.S. Lewis special gifts of grace to understand and teach the truth revealed in Christ Jesus: Grant that by this teaching we may know you, the one true God, and Jesus Christ whom you have sent; who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Sabbath Rest}
\centerline{\textit{Saturday}}
Almighty God, who after the creation of the world rested from all your works and sanctified a day of rest for all your creatures: Grant that we, putting away all earthly anxieties, may be duly prepared for the service of your sanctuary, and that our rest here upon earth may be a preparation for the eternal rest promised to your people in heaven; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
Almighty and everlasting God, who alone works great marvels: Send down upon our clergy and the congregations committed to their charge the life-giving Spirit of your grace, shower them with the continual dew of your blessing, and ignite in them a zealous love of your Gospel; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{First Reading}

\subsubsection*{The First Lesson}
\centerline{\textit{Sirach 11}}
A reading from Ecclesiasticus, the Wisdom of Jesus Son of Sirach, beginning with the eleventh chapter, the first verse\\

\begin{quote}
\textsuperscript{11} The wisdom of the humble lifts their heads high, and seats them among the great. \textsuperscript{2} Do not praise individuals for their good looks, or loathe anyone because of appearance alone. \textsuperscript{3} The bee is small among flying creatures, but what it produces is the best of sweet things. \textsuperscript{4} Do not boast about wearing fine clothes, and do not exalt yourself when you are honored; for the works of the Lord are wonderful, and his works are concealed from humankind. \textsuperscript{5} Many kings have had to sit on the ground, but one who was never thought of has worn a crown. \textsuperscript{6} Many rulers have been utterly disgraced, and the honored have been handed over to others. \textsuperscript{7} Do not find fault before you investigate; examine first, and then criticize. \textsuperscript{8} Do not answer before you listen, and do not interrupt when another is speaking. \textsuperscript{9} Do not argue about a matter that does not concern you, and do not sit with sinners when they judge a case. \textsuperscript{10} My child, do not busy yourself with many matters; if you multiply activities, you will not be held blameless. If you pursue, you will not overtake, and by fleeing you will not escape. \textsuperscript{11} There are those who work and struggle and hurry, but are so much the more in want. \textsuperscript{12} There are others who are slow and need help, who lack strength and abound in poverty; but the eyes of the Lord look kindly upon them; he lifts them out of their lowly condition \textsuperscript{13} and raises up their heads to the amazement of the many. \textsuperscript{14} Good things and bad, life and death, poverty and wealth, come from the Lord. \textsuperscript{17} The Lord’s gift remains with the devout, and his favor brings lasting success. \textsuperscript{18} One becomes rich through diligence and self-denial, and the reward allotted to him is this: \textsuperscript{19} when he says, “I have found rest, and now I shall feast on my goods! ” he does not know how long it will be until he leaves them to others and dies. \textsuperscript{20} Stand by your agreement and attend to it, and grow old in your work. \textsuperscript{21} Do not wonder at the works of a sinner, but trust in the Lord and keep at your job; for it is easy in the sight of the Lord to make the poor rich suddenly, in an instant. \textsuperscript{22} The blessing of the Lord is the reward of the pious, and quickly God causes his blessing to flourish. \textsuperscript{23} Do not say, “What do I need, and what further benefit can be mine? ” \textsuperscript{24} Do not say, “I have enough, and what harm can come to me now? ” \textsuperscript{25} In the day of prosperity, adversity is forgotten, and in the day of adversity, prosperity is not remembered. \textsuperscript{26} For it is easy for the Lord on the day of death to reward individuals according to their conduct. \textsuperscript{27} An hour’s misery makes one forget past delights, and at the close of one’s life one’s deeds are revealed. \textsuperscript{28} Call no one happy before his death; by how he ends, a person becomes known. \textsuperscript{29} Do not invite everyone into your home, for many are the tricks of the crafty. \textsuperscript{30} Like a decoy partridge in a cage, so is the mind of the proud, and like spies they observe your weakness; \textsuperscript{31} for they lie in wait, turning good into evil, and to worthy actions they attach blame. \textsuperscript{32} From a spark many coals are kindled, and a sinner lies in wait to shed blood. \textsuperscript{33} Beware of scoundrels, for they devise evil, and they may ruin your reputation forever. \textsuperscript{34} Receive strangers into your home and they will stir up trouble for you, and will make you a stranger to your own family.
\end{quote}

Here ends the Reading.\\

\subsection*{Collect(s) of the Day}

\subsubsection*{Collect of the Day}
\centerline{\textit{The First Sunday in Advent}}
Almighty God, give us grace to cast away the works of darkness, and put on the armor of light, now in the time of this mortal life in which your Son Jesus Christ came to visit us in great humility; that in the last day, when he shall come again in his glorious majesty to judge both the living and the dead, we may rise to the life immortal; through him who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsection*{Additional Collects}

\subsubsection*{A Collect for Strength to Await Christ's Return}
\centerline{\textit{Sunday}}
O God our King, by the resurrection of your Son Jesus Christ on the first day of the week, you conquered sin, put death to flight, and gave us the hope of everlasting life: Redeem all our days by this victory; forgive our sins, banish our fears, make us bold to praise you and to do your will; and steel us to wait for the consummation of your kingdom on the last great Day; through Jesus Christ our Lord.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
\subsubsection*{A Prayer for Mission}
Lord Jesus Christ, you stretched out your arms of love on the hard wood of the Cross that everyone might come within the reach of your saving embrace: So clothe us in your Spirit that we, reaching forth our hands in love, may bring those who do not know you to the knowledge and love of you; for the honor of your Name.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\

\subsubsection*{A Prayer of St. John Chrysostom}
Almighty God, you have given us grace at this time, with one accord to make our common supplications to you; and you have promised through your well-beloved Son that when two or three are gathered together in his Name you will grant their requests: Fulfill now, O Lord, our desires and petitions as may be best for us; granting us in this world knowledge of your truth, and in the age to come life everlasting.\\
\textbf{Amen.}\\
